review: I purchased the device to use in hotel rooms. The meager instructions say simply to plug in the device and begin using it. I tested it on my home system and it worked nicely. However, when I tried it on a hotel system it did not work at all. I was able to insert it into the appropriate tv port but nothing happened. The tv operated the same as before with no new access to Internet . I suspect the hotel tv system was designed to prevent guests from by-passing their pay per view system.

author: Moiz Bohra

review: I purchased this because I liked the low profile look of it (but it still uses a chord) and the fact that the remote doesn't need to be pointed at the unit. Also, like a Roku or Apple tv I can have all of the apps I need to watch everything I need. It's so simple yet somehow it has figured out a way to fail, and fail all of the time.When it arrived I also had a new AT&T; service started with the premium internet option. No streaming issues, quick downloads, etc. This wireless router is within 1 foot of my firestick but that doesn't stop it from lagging, buffering, and fluctuating picture quality. You might say, well it's probably your internet connection or data rate. But it's not, my computer even my Wii which I've had as long as I can remember works without issue. Right now as I am typing this it is unable to hold a wireless connection for more than 10 seconds it seems. It connects, I try to watch something on hulu or netflix and I get an empty screen. I try to check for system updates and I can't because it drops the signal, but every time I go to check the signal its fine. Very frustrating. It is at the point where the home menu will not even display because it says it has no signal, yet everything else in the house does. I have rebooted, trouble shooted, and damn near thrown it out the window.Spend the extra couple bucks and get something reliable like a Roku or Apple Tv.
author: Brian LaBarbera
